conclusion: Analyze the propagation of each wave from their respective sources to find the time when they reach the same point.
Wave source 1 is at x = -0.2 m and propagates in the positive x-direction.
Wave source 2 is at x = 1.2 m and propagates in the negative x-direction.
Both waves have a wave speed v = 0.4 m/s.
The two waves will meet at some point x between x = -0.2 m and x = 1.2 m, denoted as x_m.
Distance traveled by the wave from x = -0.2 m to x_m is d_1 = x_m + 0.2.
Distance traveled by the wave from x = 1.2 m to x_m is d_2 = 1.2 - x_m.
Set up the equation for the time taken by each wave to reach x_m: d_1/v = d_2/v.
Substitute d_1 and d_2 into the equation: (x_m + 0.2)/0.4 = (1.2 - x_m)/0.4.
Calculate the time taken for the wave from x = -0.2 m to travel to x = 0.5 m: d_1 = 0.7 m, t = 0.7/0.4 = 1.75 s.
Calculate the time taken for the wave from x = 1.2 m to travel to x = 0.5 m: d_2 = 0.7 m, t = 0.7/0.4 = 1.75 s.
Both calculations confirm that the time taken for the waves to meet is 1.75 seconds.
The two waves meet at t = 1.75 seconds.
